entry.title: 99designs Logo Contests
entry.summary: The logo for Coding Across America came from a contest on 99designs. This was my first experience with 99designs. Overall I am really happy with how I spent my $299. This post will help you avoid some of the rookie mistakes I made so that you get the most value out of your experience.

entry.title: CopperEgg
entry.summary:
CopperEgg is tech company based in Austin, TX that provides a software-as-a-service platform for software infrastructure monitoring and management.

CopperEgg's service started as a product for analyzing network traffic. After the initial concept was built, the team realized they could apply similar methods to other infrastructure metrics such as CPU utilization, memory usage, and storage performance.

Monitoring server infrastructure is simple in theory, but becomes extremely complicated when scaling to hundreds or thousands of servers. CopperEgg is designed to solve that problem by giving continuous near real-time feedback to systems administrators and DevOps teams.

One of the use cases we talked through is when development teams apply infrastructure changes to their production environments. The teams can then immediately see the results of those changes through CopperEgg's metrics and understand the impact of those changes. Writing similar monitoring software in-house would be an enormous undertaking which is why CopperEgg's software-as-a-service value proposition is an easy justification in infrastructure environments with many servers.

While at first it would appear that CopperEgg's offering is similar to New Relic's platform, they are attacking monitoring from two different perspectives.

Me next to CopperEgg's logo at their office while holding "The Egg"

To learn more about CopperEgg, check out their launch articles in InfoWorld and ReadWrite.

If you liked this post, you should also check out my posts on Capital Factory and HumanGeo.

entry.title: Tech Wildcatters
entry.summary:
Tech Wildcatters is a Dallas-based startup accelerator focused on early stage business-to-business (B2B) companies.

Tech Wildcatters is commonly ranked among the best accelerator programs in the nation by Forbes and other publications.

Tech Wildcatters' current founders class

Customer Funded Development

An interesting, semi-obvious trend for startups I noticed in Dallas was the extensive B2B focus.

entry.title: The Common Desk
entry.summary:
The Common Desk is a co-working space in the Deep Ellum area of Dallas, Texas.

Nick, the founder of The Common Desk.

entry.title: Memphis Seed Hatchery Dinner
entry.summary: Last night I had great company for dinner: the founders of the current Memphis Seed Hatchery class. We ate out at Bari after I sat in on their business development class from 5:30 to 6:30pm.
